articles.headline: At Venezuela’s Border, a Strange and Deadly Showdown Over Aid
articles.snippet: The confrontation between Maduro and the opposition now includes dueling concerts, visiting presidents, plotting military defectors — and at least two deaths.
articles.abstract: The confrontation between Maduro and the opposition now includes dueling concerts, visiting presidents, plotting military defectors — and at least two deaths.
articles.lead_paragraph: CÚCUTA, Colombia — The political showdown over the delivery of aid to Venezuela turned deadly Friday when its security forces fired on protesters near the country’s Brazilian border, killing two and wounding a dozen in a confrontation that could signal a more violent and destabilizing struggle over who can claim to be the country’s legitimate leader.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Casey, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Ernesto Londoño

articles.headline: A Teacher’s Student Loans Were Forgiven. Then FedLoan Wrecked His Credit.
articles.snippet: Jed Shafer thought his work navigating the troubled public service loan forgiveness program was finished. He found out he was wrong when Lowe’s turned him away at the register.
articles.abstract: Jed Shafer thought his work navigating the troubled public service loan forgiveness program was finished. He found out he was wrong when Lowe’s turned him away at the register.
articles.lead_paragraph: When nine refund checks landed in his mailbox a few months ago, Jed Shafer figured he was finally done with his student loan.
articles.byline: By Ron Lieber

articles.headline: How Amy Klobuchar Treats Her Staff
articles.snippet: Interviews with more than two dozen former staff members and internal emails reviewed by The Times reveal demeaning and unusual behavior by Ms. Klobuchar toward her subordinates.
articles.abstract: Interviews with more than two dozen former staff members and internal emails reviewed by The Times reveal demeaning and unusual behavior by Ms. Klobuchar toward her subordinates.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator Amy Klobuchar was hungry, forkless and losing patience.
articles.byline: By Matt Flegenheimer and Sydney Ember

articles.headline: Huawei’s Plight Hangs Over Wireless Industry Showcase
articles.snippet: The potential bans of Huawei technology is overshadowing the mobile phone industry’s biggest annual event in Barcelona.
articles.abstract: The potential bans of Huawei technology is overshadowing the mobile phone industry’s biggest annual event in Barcelona.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Wireless carriers have for years said the next generation network, known as 5G, will provide not only hyper-fast mobile phone speeds, but breakthroughs for data-heavy technologies like autonomous vehicles, robotics and artificial intelligence.
articles.byline: By Adam Satariano

articles.headline: U.S. and China Extend Talks, but Final Deal Remains Elusive
articles.snippet: President Trump said there was a “very, very good chance” of a trade deal with China being reached when he meets with the Chinese president in March.
articles.abstract: President Trump said there was a “very, very good chance” of a trade deal with China being reached when he meets with the Chinese president in March.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump said the United States and China were moving closer toward a trade agreement and suggested that the fate of Huawei, the Chinese telecom giant facing criminal charges along with its chief financial officer, could be resolved as part of a final trade deal with Beijing.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: Cohen Gave Prosecutors New Information on the Trump Family Business
articles.snippet: President Trump’s former lawyer, Michael D. Cohen, discussed possible irregularities at the Trump Organization. He wants a reduced prison sentence.
articles.abstract: President Trump’s former lawyer, Michael D. Cohen, discussed possible irregularities at the Trump Organization. He wants a reduced prison sentence.
articles.lead_paragraph: Michael D. Cohen, President Trump’s former lawyer and fixer, met last month with federal prosecutors in Manhattan, offering information about possible irregularities within the president’s family business and about a donor to the inaugural committee, according to people familiar with the matter.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess, William K. Rashbaum and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Kraft Tests How Much Costs Can Be Cut as Tastes Change
articles.snippet: The reputations of some of the world’s most powerful investors rest on whether they can get consumers excited again about Kraft macaroni and cheese.
articles.abstract: The reputations of some of the world’s most powerful investors rest on whether they can get consumers excited again about Kraft macaroni and cheese.
articles.lead_paragraph: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________
articles.byline: By Peter Eavis

articles.headline: Do Not Disturb: How I Ditched My Phone and Unbroke My Brain
articles.snippet: I couldn’t read a book, watch a full-length movie or sustain a long conversation. Late last year, I decided enough was enough.
articles.abstract: I couldn’t read a book, watch a full-length movie or sustain a long conversation. Late last year, I decided enough was enough.
articles.lead_paragraph: My name is Kevin, and I have a phone problem.
articles.byline: By Kevin Roose

articles.headline: Some Aid From Brazil Pierces Venezuela’s Blockade, but Deadly Violence Erupts
articles.snippet: In a showdown with the Maduro government, Venezuela’s opposition managed to get a small truckload of supplies in from Brazil, but elsewhere its effort appeared stalled.
articles.abstract: In a showdown with the Maduro government, Venezuela’s opposition managed to get a small truckload of supplies in from Brazil, but elsewhere its effort appeared stalled.
articles.lead_paragraph: CÚCUTA, Colombia — An ambitious plan by Venezuela’s opposition to peacefully import foreign aid in truck convoys degenerated into deadly skirmishes Saturday along the impoverished country’s borders, with a smattering of supplies getting through but most of it blocked by armed loyalists of President Nicolás Maduro.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Casey, Albinson Linares and Anatoly Kurmanaev

articles.headline: Health Care and Insurance Industries Mobilize to Kill ‘Medicare for All’
articles.snippet: Doctors, hospitals, drug companies and insurers have a simple message: The Affordable Care Act works reasonably well and should be improved, not repealed or replaced with a big new public program.
articles.abstract: Doctors, hospitals, drug companies and insurers have a simple message: The Affordable Care Act works reasonably well and should be improved, not repealed or replaced with a big new public program.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Even before Democrats finish drafting bills to create a single-payer health care system, the health care and insurance industries have assembled a small army of lobbyists to kill “Medicare for all,” an idea that is mocked publicly but is being greeted privately with increasing seriousness.
articles.byline: By Robert Pear

articles.headline: From Screen to Scorn: For Jussie Smollett, a Life of Arts and Activism Is Upended
articles.snippet: Given the actor’s long history in show business and political causes, it is all the more baffling to friends that he would risk so much.
articles.abstract: Given the actor’s long history in show business and political causes, it is all the more baffling to friends that he would risk so much.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Ever since he was a child actor growing up in a show-business family, Jussie Smollett’s life blended activism with the make-believe worlds of television and movies.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy, Michael Cooper, Serge F. Kovaleski and Alyssa Schukar

articles.headline: Russian Spy or Hustling Political Operative? The Enigmatic Figure at the Heart of Mueller’s Inquiry
articles.snippet: Konstantin V. Kilimnik is central to two of the most tantalizing elements in the special counsel’s investigation of possible collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia.
articles.abstract: Konstantin V. Kilimnik is central to two of the most tantalizing elements in the special counsel’s investigation of possible collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the nearly two years that the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, has been investigating whether there was collusion between Russia and the Trump campaign, few figures seem to have offered more tantalizing leads than Konstantin V. Kilimnik.
articles.byline: By Kenneth P. Vogel and Andrew E. Kramer

articles.headline: China’s Entrepreneurs Are Wary of Its Future
articles.snippet: Behind the scenes, businesspeople worry that Beijing has become more interested in solidifying its control over people’s lives than promoting economic growth.
articles.abstract: Behind the scenes, businesspeople worry that Beijing has become more interested in solidifying its control over people’s lives than promoting economic growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: Chen Tianyong, a Chinese real estate developer in Shanghai, boarded a flight to Malta last month with no plans to return anytime soon.
articles.byline: By Li Yuan

articles.headline: Pope Francis Ends Landmark Sex Abuse Meeting With Strong Words, but Few Actions
articles.snippet: Rather than changing church law himself, Francis used the meeting to try to convince the world’s bishops to acknowledge the scope of the abuse problem and to hold themselves accountable for fixing it.
articles.abstract: Rather than changing church law himself, Francis used the meeting to try to convince the world’s bishops to acknowledge the scope of the abuse problem and to hold themselves accountable for fixing it.
articles.lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — Pope Francis ended a landmark Vatican meeting on clerical sexual abuse by calling “for an all-out battle against the abuse of minors” and insisting that the church needed to protect children “from ravenous wolves.”
articles.byline: By Jason Horowitz and Elizabeth Dias

articles.headline: Defender of World Order or Trump Mouthpiece? Pompeo Is Tested by North Korea, Iran and U.S. Allies
articles.snippet: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo works hard at being President Trump’s most loyal cabinet member and greatest evangelist of “America First.” But the world is pushing back.
articles.abstract: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo works hard at being President Trump’s most loyal cabinet member and greatest evangelist of “America First.” But the world is pushing back.
articles.lead_paragraph: WARSAW — In the eyes of Mike Pompeo, the day was shaping up to be one of his most commanding displays of diplomacy since becoming secretary of state. Months of planning had finally yielded a meeting among reluctant European officials, Arab leaders and the Israeli prime minister to strategize over confronting Iran.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Edward Wong

articles.headline: China’s Tech Firms Are Mapping Pig Faces
articles.snippet: As a devastating disease afflicts the country’s swine, companies are scrambling to roll out facial and voice recognition and other unproven ways to save them.
articles.abstract: As a devastating disease afflicts the country’s swine, companies are scrambling to roll out facial and voice recognition and other unproven ways to save them.
articles.lead_paragraph: A database of every pig’s face. Voice scans that detect hogs with a cough. Robots that dispense just the right amount of feed.
articles.byline: By Sui-Lee Wee and Elsie Chen

articles.headline: In Conservative Districts, Democrats Have to Answer for Party’s Left Wing
articles.snippet: The moderates who secured the Democratic House majority are feeling the heat from the new progressives who took seats in liberal bastions — and the constituents at home who oppose them.
articles.abstract: The moderates who secured the Democratic House majority are feeling the heat from the new progressives who took seats in liberal bastions — and the constituents at home who oppose them.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEPHI, Utah — In the suburbs of Salt Lake City, Representative Ben McAdams, a freshman, was grilled by constituents about the “socialism” and “anti-Semitism” that they saw coming out of the new Democratic House.
articles.byline: By Catie Edmondson and Emily Cochrane

articles.headline: Trump Delays a Tariff Deadline, Citing Progress in China Trade Talks
articles.snippet: The president, who has been eager to cut a deal with Beijing, said the negotiators had forged a compromise on key issues but few details have been released.
articles.abstract: The president, who has been eager to cut a deal with Beijing, said the negotiators had forged a compromise on key issues but few details have been released.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump delayed his own deadline to increase tariffs on Chinese goods on Sunday as his administration continues a monthslong effort to persuade Beijing to make significant structural changes to its economy that have so far proved elusive.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: Netanyahu Sparks Outrage Over Pact With Racist Party
articles.snippet: An increasingly desperate Israeli prime minister has aggravated already fraught relations between Israel and Jews in the diaspora.
articles.abstract: An increasingly desperate Israeli prime minister has aggravated already fraught relations between Israel and Jews in the diaspora.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has made something of an art form of cutting deals with small Israeli political parties, but his latest alliance has earned him denunciations from quarters where he has usually been able to count on unshakable support.
articles.byline: By David M. Halbfinger

articles.headline: ‘Austerity, That’s What I Know’: The Making of a Young U.K. Socialist
articles.snippet: Alex McIntyre, 19, was brought up in a Britain being reshaped by government cuts. He gave up on capitalism after a year in college.
articles.abstract: Alex McIntyre, 19, was brought up in a Britain being reshaped by government cuts. He gave up on capitalism after a year in college.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRIGHTON, England — Alex McIntyre was raised on budget cuts.
articles.byline: By Ellen Barry

articles.headline: Tax the Rich? Here’s How to Do It (Sensibly)
articles.snippet: Should there be a wealth tax on the richest Americans? A top bracket of 70 percent? Or we could just close these gaping loopholes.
articles.abstract: Should there be a wealth tax on the richest Americans? A top bracket of 70 percent? Or we could just close these gaping loopholes.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: Rust Belt, Sun Belt or Both? Democrats Seek the Best Route to the White House
articles.snippet: Democrats are split over whether to redouble their efforts to win back the industrial heartland, or turn their attention to more demographically promising states like Georgia and Arizona.
articles.abstract: Democrats are split over whether to redouble their efforts to win back the industrial heartland, or turn their attention to more demographically promising states like Georgia and Arizona.
articles.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — At the very first event of her first full day in Iowa as a presidential candidate, Senator Kamala Harris was greeted by a Democratic voter who delivered a pointed recommendation about the best path to the White House.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: 2019 Is a Sensitive Year for China. Xi Is Nervous.
articles.snippet: President Trump wants big changes from China. But China’s leader is seeking security in a year that includes the 30th anniversary of the Tiananmen bloodshed.
articles.abstract: President Trump wants big changes from China. But China’s leader is seeking security in a year that includes the 30th anniversary of the Tiananmen bloodshed.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China’s leader, Xi Jinping, abruptly summoned hundreds of officials to Beijing recently, forcing some to reschedule long-planned local assemblies. The meeting seemed orchestrated to convey anxious urgency. The Communist Party, Mr. Xi told the officials, faces major risks on all fronts and must batten down the hatches.
articles.byline: By Chris Buckley
